docs.lead_paragraph: TECHNOLOGY has always been the dentist's stock in trade. From high-speed drills to X-rays, the men and women who pull and preserve teeth have often turned to technology to take their practice one more step beyond the image of the torture chamber. It's no surprise then, that dentists are going digital. Patients will still have to open wide, of course, to have cavities filled and teeth removed. Some things never change. But X-ray film may one day be replaced by a wafer-size sensor that electronically generates an X-ray image on a chair-side monitor. The dental mirror may be replaced, or at least augmented, by a slender fiber-optic tool that uses a miniature video camera to show incipient trouble spots. And along with the fiber-optic wand may come a range of computerized devices that inject Novocain, check the health of the gums and even analyze the bite -- no more chomping and grinding the teeth on squares of black paper.

headline.main: Overbite, Underbite, Megabyte: Dentistry Gets an Upgrade

docs.abstract: High-technology dental equipment offers promise of faster treatments, less exposure to X-rays and less pain; some dentists resist digital gadgets, questioning their cost and value; many are using computers for small jobs; photo (M)
docs.snippet: TECHNOLOGY has always been the dentist's stock in trade. From high-speed drills to X-rays, the men and women who pull and preserve teeth have often turned to technology to take their practice one more step beyond the image of the torture chamber....

docs.lead_paragraph: It took 15 years, from when the first plans were drawn up in 1983 until tenants started moving in earlier this year, to turn Brooklyn's Renaissance Plaza from a concept into a reality. But now it is there, its front on Adams Street in the borough's downtown district and complete with 820,000 square feet of Class A office space, a 376-room Marriott hotel that began receiving guests in July, and 1,100 underground parking spaces. ''When I had a tenant I didn't have the financing, and when I had the financing I didn't have a tenant,'' said Joshua Muss of the Muss Development Company, explaining the long struggle to bring the project to fruition.

headline.main: Commercial Real Estate; Assembling Brooklyn's Renaissance Plaza Puzzle

docs.abstract: Commercial Real Estate column discusses development, begun in 1983, of Brooklyn's Renaissance Plaza; plaza, which will have its official opening on Nov 18, described (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Taxi executives, worried that the city wants to modify or eliminate the cab-leasing system that has become an economic linchpin of the industry, proposed a pilot program yesterday under which 100 cabbies would work on commission, as most did until the 1980's. Industry leaders say that leasing -- a policy that transformed cabbies from fleet employees into independent contractors who pay up to $110 per shift for use of a car -- brought the taxi business back from the brink of disaster. But many drivers have complained that the policy, which was legalized in 1979, has led drivers to work longer hours for lower wages. The system has also been cited frequently in recent months as contributing to reckless driving and an increase in accidents during the 1990's.

headline.main: Old Wage Plan for Cabbies Gets Another Look

docs.lead_paragraph: Government efforts to avoid a problem that threatens to shut down computers on Jan. 1, 2000, could cost Medicare recipients as much as $570 million in savings on their co-payments. Elderly and disabled Americans covered by Medicare are expected to pay 20 percent of the bills for most medical care, either out of their own pockets or by buying private supplemental insurance.
